both the terms of the equation will be positive 
between the limits mentioned. Thus there 
is no value of p less than p[squared] that will verify 
the equation (7).
It is proved in the Paper (p. 62) that 
for every assumed value of T[squared], there is a 
positive value of p, that will verify the 
equation (7): and, as it has now been 
shown that the values of p which verify 
that equation cannot be less than p[squared], 
they must be all greater than p[squared].
Further in the differential equation (A) 
dV/[delta]p cannot be zero: because T[squared] increasing without limits, dV/TdT.TdT is es:
sentially positive. Now, for all values of 
p between p[squared] and 3, dV/[delta]p is negative: wherefore 
the same function will continue to be 
negative in the equation (A) for all values of p and T[squared]: and 
as dV/[delta]p.dp is also negative, dp must be 
positive, so that p will increase above 
p [squared] without limit.
If the sign of [delta]V/dp be changed, the re:
sult will be positive: and hence, observing 
that x is contained between 0 and 1, we ob:
tain a condition between any two values 
of p and T[squared] that satisfy the equation (7), 
namely
